author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Returns to No. 1 as ‘Folklore’ Sales Pass 1 Million
description: The singer and songwriter’s surprise July release is the only album to cross the million-sales mark so far this year.
content: A few years ago, in what now seems another lifetime of the music industry, it was not so uncommon for popular albums to sell a million copies. Taylor Swift sold that many in a single week four albums in a row. Adele sold eight million in 2015 alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Exports of Used Cars Are a Pollution Problem, U.N. Warns
description: Rich countries are sending millions of older, dirtier vehicles abroad, in a trade that’s largely unregulated, even as they mandate cleaner cars at home.
content: WASHINGTON — In recent decades, the United States and Europe have gone to considerable lengths to mandate cleaner, more efficient cars at home. But at the same time, they are shipping millions of their oldest and worst-polluting vehicles to poorer countries overseas in a largely unregulated trade that now poses serious health and environmental hazards, the United Nations warned on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman and Luce Brett
title: ‘We Don’t Have to Put Up With This’: A Candid Conversation About Bodies
description: What is the price we all pay by not having the conversation, however uncomfortable, about continence, childbirth, changing bodies and taboos?
content: — Luce Brett, the author of “PMSL: Or How I Literally Pissed Myself Laughing and Survived the Last Taboo to Tell the Tale,” about her battle with postpartum incontinence
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Students and Teachers, Tell Us About Your Experience With the Civil Conversation Challenge
description: Our staff has been delighted by the response, but we’d love to hear what it was like for you.
content: Our 2020 Civil Conversation Challenge began on Sept. 22 and ends this Friday, Oct. 30. Our staff has been thrilled to watch the comments come in — more than 6,000 so far — and to observe the fascinating, productive conversations among teenagers across regions and backgrounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
title: The Erasure of Mesut Özil
description: A year ago, he was one of the Premier League’s highest-paid players. Now, after angering China and refusing a pay cut, he has simply vanished.
content: LONDON — Everything started with a tweet. Mesut Özil knew the risks, in December last year, when he decided to offer a startling, public denunciation both of China’s treatment of the Uighurs, a largely Muslim minority in the region of Xinjiang, and the complicit silence of the international community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: In Boston, someone set fire to a ballot drop box. Officials called it a ‘disgrace to democracy.’
description: Massachusetts officials have ordered increased security around drop boxes used to collect mail-in ballots after what they said was an arson attack on one in Boston.
content: Massachusetts officials have ordered increased security around drop boxes used to collect mail-in ballots after what they said was an arson attack on one in Boston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Piccoli and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: The Strand Calls for Help, and Book Lovers Answer
description: “It’s awkward because the track record for the ownership here is not great,” one customer said. “But it’s also an institution. My parents shopped here.”
content: For months, the Strand bookstore in downtown Manhattan, from its fiction stacks to its cookbook section to its rare books, has been nearly deserted. But on Sunday, half an hour before the store was scheduled to open, about a dozen people lined up in the cool fall breeze, waiting to get inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: A Malaria Mystery, Partly Solved: What Happens When the Rains End?
description: A study in Mali suggests that malaria parasites hide out during the dry season by altering the properties of red blood cells.
content: Each year malaria kills roughly 400,000 people, most of them children and pregnant women in Africa. Scientists have long known that most of those fevers and deaths occur during the rainy months, when mosquitoes abound. But how does the disease persist during the long dry seasons, when almost no one falls ill and there are few mosquitoes to carry the tiny malaria parasite from one human host to another?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips and Eshe Nelson
title: Wall St. Alarm at Surge of Virus Sends Stocks and Oil Lower
description: Investors get “a reality check about what a renewed round of lockdowns will have on earnings.”
content: A rise in coronavirus cases in the United States, new restrictions on activity in Europe and a standoff in Washington over aid for struggling businesses and out-of-work Americans left investors reeling on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma and Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Iran’s Oil Sector
description: The Trump administration is trying to fortify its campaign of maximum pressure against Iran from being reversed by a potential Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration imposed sweeping economic sanctions against Iran’s oil sector on Monday as tensions between Washington and Tehran continue to escalate in the days leading up to the American presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: There’s Water and Ice on the Moon, and in More Places Than NASA Thought
description: Future astronauts seeking water on the moon may not need to go into the most treacherous craters in its polar regions to find it.
content: Future astronauts headed to the moon may have an easier time finding water and digging up ice than had been thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Colleges Are Slashing Budgets
description: The pandemic has pushed higher education institutions to the brink.
content: It’s happening across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Glenn Thrush
title: Biden, in Sign of Confidence, Will Visit Iowa in Race’s Final Days
description: Appearing newly emboldened, the Democratic nominee also said he thought he would win Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, three critical battleground states.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will travel to Iowa this week, he announced on Monday, a sign of confidence that suggests his campaign is significantly expanding its electoral map with just eight days left in the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Forget Halloween. Children Are Frightening Year-Round.
description: Why little kids have a special ability to creep out their parents.
content: Some parents don’t need spooky stories or horror movies. The real terror already lives within the walls of their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Mary Williams Walsh and Matt Phillips
title: Apollo Clients Await Inquiry’s Findings on Chief and Jeffrey Epstein
description: Leon Black, Apollo Global Management’s co-founder and leader, has been facing questions from investors over his ties to the convicted sex offender. One has already opted to withhold new investment.
content: Leon Black helped start Apollo Global Management three decades ago out of the ashes of a junk-bond scandal and built a $400 billion private-equity powerhouse, handling the investments of institutions around the globe, from public pension systems in California to sovereign wealth funds controlled by foreign governments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump plans to swear Barrett in at the White House later tonight, officials say.
description: President Trump is likely to hold a swearing-in ceremony at the White House on Monday night for Judge Amy Coney Barrett following the vote to confirm her to the Supreme Court, officials said.
content: President Trump is likely to hold a swearing-in ceremony at the White House on Monday night for Judge Amy Coney Barrett following the vote to confirm her to the Supreme Court, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Clayton Kershaw Steadies Dodgers and Puts a World Series Within Reach
description: Los Angeles rebounded after a wild loss on Saturday to beat the Tampa Bay Rays in Game 5 and move to within one win of a championship.
content: There were no crazy comebacks this time, no stumbling, staggering routes to home plate and no wild outfield celebration like the night before. Some relative normalcy returned to the World Series on Sunday as the Los Angeles Dodgers inched closer to their first title in 32 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Share Your Story of Keeping America Fed
description: We want to hear from farmers, meatpackers, grocers and other essential workers who have kept the country fed throughout the pandemic.
content: Every American depends on a chain of people stretching from farms and fisheries to their front doors. While much of the country remained at home as the coronavirus spread, this group worked to feed the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The world’s largest I.P.O.
content: The Chinese financial technology titan is set to raise around $34 billion when its shares begin trading in Hong Kong and Shanghai in the coming weeks. That would make its initial public offering the largest on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Democrats in Many Races Are Moderates. Republicans Cast Them as Radicals.
description: Democrats chose Senate candidates who have rejected progressive policies. That hasn’t stopped Republicans from trying to paint them as extreme.
content: DONNELLSON, Iowa — “Where’d you get these apples?” asked Theresa Greenfield, the Democratic Senate candidate turned pie taster at a farm in Southeast Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Sex Cult Leader, Facing Life Sentence, Regrets Nothing
description: Several victims are expected to testify when Keith Raniere, the founder of Nxivm, is sentenced this week for sex trafficking, extortion and other crimes.
content: [Read our latest coverage of Keith Raniere’s sentencing.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hwaida Saad and Carlotta Gall
title: Russian Airstrikes Kill Dozens of Turkish-Backed Rebels in Syria
description: Analysts say the assault, which violated a seven-month truce, could be seen as a warning to Ankara.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russian war planes struck a camp of Turkish-backed rebel fighters in northwestern Syria on Monday, killing dozens of Syrian fighters as well as civilians harvesting olives nearby, according to a rebel spokesman, in the bloodiest surge in violence since a cease-fire came into effect seven months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Even Cowboys Get the Blues
description: Dallas (2-5) began its season with loads of optimism. But injuries to Dak Prescott and Andy Dalton, and a bad loss to Washington, have the team unloading players.
content: When a team is winning, it is all smiles and agreement in the clubhouse. But when a team loses a lot, the camaraderie gets fractured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John F. Kerry
title: China’s Chance to Save Antarctic Sea Life
description: Twenty-four countries and the E.U. have agreed to create three marine parks, which would ban fishing and other industrial activity. But to become a reality, China must also agree.
content: Even as the United States and China confront deep disagreements, there is a global challenge that simply won’t wait for the resolution of our differences: climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
title: British Commandos Storm Tanker, Ending Standoff in English Channel
description: The captain of the ship had reported that a group of stowaways on board was threatening the crew. Ten hours later, special forces brought the standoff to a close.
content: LONDON — Under the cover of darkness, British commandos slid down ropes from four Navy helicopters hovering over the English Channel and onto the deck of an oil tanker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Black Senate Candidates in the South Tell Democrats to ‘Meet the Moment’
description: Several Black Democrats are running competitively in conservative states, and they are doing so by talking explicitly about race.
content: HORN LAKE, Miss. — Mike Espy and Jaime Harrison, two of the five Black Senate candidates in the South this year, may belong to different political generations, but they both came up in a Democratic Party where African-American politicians didn’t talk directly about race in campaigns against white opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: With a little more than a week until Election Day, Trump and Biden make their closing pitches on ‘60 Minutes.’
description: Nine days before Election Day, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered sharply divergent visions for the country, including the coronavirus pandemic, in wide-ranging interviews on “60 Minutes.”
content: Nine days before Election Day, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered sharply divergent visions for the country, including the coronavirus pandemic, in wide-ranging interviews on “60 Minutes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Missing From Supreme Court’s Election Cases: Reasons for Its Rulings
description: In a series of terse, unsigned orders, the court has been deciding many election disputes on its “shadow docket” without a murmur of explanation.
content: WASHINGTON — At least nine times since April, the Supreme Court has issued rulings in election disputes. Or perhaps “rulings” is too generous a word for those unsigned orders, which addressed matters as consequential as absentee voting during the pandemic in Alabama, South Carolina and Texas, and the potential disenfranchisement of hundreds of thousands of people with felony convictions in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Jeremy Engle
title: Should Media Literacy Be a Required Course in School?
description: Can your generation distinguish reliable from unreliable information on the internet? How much do you think that matters?
content: Do you think of yourself as a savvy news consumer? What about your friends? Is your generation good at distinguishing reliable from unreliable information on the internet? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Trump Economy
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: President Trump is not running a re-election campaign based mostly on policy. He has released no detailed agenda for a second term, and the Republican Party did not publish a new platform at its convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Belarus Opposition Calls General Strike, as Protesters Gird for Long Fight
description: The country’s autocratic ruler, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, is hanging on. But his fate may be decided in Moscow, where patience is wearing thin.
content: MOSCOW — For close to three months, protesters in Belarus have been beaten, jailed, pepper-sprayed, fined and exiled. But Oksana Koltovich, a bar and beauty salon owner in the country’s capital, Minsk, is undeterred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: 5 Lessons on Voter Misinformation From Kentucky’s Election in 2019
description: The incumbent governor and some of his allies argued, without showing any evidence, that there were voting irregularities and fraud.
content: Local election officials, politicians and disinformation researchers continue to express concern about how misinformation about voting could disrupt Election Day next week. False and misleading information, research shows, has already been spreading widely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Ant Group Set to Raise $34 Billion in World’s Biggest I.P.O.
description: The Alibaba online finance spinoff, which offers people in China a one-stop shop for loans, investments and more, will list shares in Hong Kong and Shanghai.
content: Ant Group, the Chinese financial technology titan, is set to raise around $34 billion when its shares begin trading in Hong Kong and Shanghai in the coming weeks, which would make its initial public offering the largest on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Joe Biden, Generic Democrat
description: He was barely seen in public today, just eight days before the election — but that’s all part of the strategy.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Justice Clarence Thomas will give the oath to Judge Amy Coney Barrett, a White House official said.
description: Justice Clarence Thomas will give the constitutional oath to Judge Amy Coney Barrett at the White House on Monday night after she is officially confirmed to the Supreme Court by the Senate, a White House official said.
content: Justice Clarence Thomas will give the constitutional oath to Judge Amy Coney Barrett at the White House on Monday night after she is officially confirmed to the Supreme Court by the Senate, a White House official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirby Ferguson
title: What Do We Do About Q?
description: The conspiracy theories seem ridiculous, but the consequences are real.
content: A global cabal of celebrity pedophiles? Trafficked children being sold online through a furniture website? And Donald Trump about to rescue us from it all?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Villasana
title: Witnessing Peru’s Enduring, if Altered, Snow Star Festival
description: Rising temperatures and melting glaciers have changed key aspects of the age-old Peruvian festival of Qoyllur Rit’i. Still, the celebrations persist.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Danielle Villasana shares a collection of images from southeastern Peru.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Game day in Green Bay: Empty sports bars, full hospitals.
description: On Sunday, an N.F.L. game day when the Green Bay Packers were taking it to the Texans in Houston, the scene in the Packers’ Wisconsin hometown was noticeably subdued, as the coronavirus surged in the state and people mostly avoided the bars that are usually jammed when the Packers are playing.
content: On Sunday, an N.F.L. game day when the Green Bay Packers were taking it to the Texans in Houston, the scene in the Packers’ Wisconsin hometown was noticeably subdued, as the coronavirus surged in the state and people mostly avoided the bars that are usually jammed when the Packers are playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Hospitals across the U.S. and Europe are reaching capacity at a rapid pace.
content: In an ominous sign of the strength of latest coronavirus surge, hospitals across the U.S. and Europe are reaching capacity at a rapid pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why Dunkin’ Is Worth Nearly $9 Billion
description: The restaurant chain is a pandemic success story.
content: This Nov. 17 and 18, DealBook is holding our first Online Summit. Join us as we welcome the most consequential newsmakers in business, policy and culture to explore the pivotal questions of the moment — and the future. Watch from anywhere, free of charge. Register now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: First Coronavirus Hit, Then They Got Bedbugs
description: Three roommates support each other through the pandemic and fumigation, and luck into a bigger apartment for the same price.
content: By June, things were looking up for Posey Bartol and Theresa Alexander, two actors who lost their jobs and their third roommate at the start of the pandemic. They had finally found someone to take over the empty bedroom in their Hamilton Heights apartment, their unemployment checks had come through, and after 90 days of rarely venturing out, they had started volunteering with the #OpenYourLobby campaign for Black Lives Matter protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Zeta Is Downgraded on the Way to the Gulf Coast
description: The storm, which was a Category 1 hurricane, was expected to restrengthen later on Tuesday.
content: Hurricane Zeta, which brought torrential rains as it slammed into the Yucatán Peninsula of Mexico, was downgraded to a tropical storm on Tuesday morning. It offered further evidence that this hurricane season has not only been extremely active, but also extremely wet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Dunkin’ Brands has done well in the pandemic. Now it’s a $9 billion takeover target.
description: Dunkin’ Brands, the parent of Dunkin’ and Baskin Robbins, is negotiating with a private equity-backed company for a sale that values the restaurant chain at nearly $9 billion. The potential takeover, reported first by The New York Times on Sunday, would come at a 20 percent premium to Dunkin’s share price on Friday, which was already trading near a high.
content: Dunkin’ Brands, the parent of Dunkin’ and Baskin Robbins, is negotiating with a private equity-backed company for a sale that values the restaurant chain at nearly $9 billion. The potential takeover, reported first by The New York Times on Sunday, would come at a 20 percent premium to Dunkin’s share price on Friday, which was already trading near a high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Kushner, Employing Racist Stereotype, Questions if Black Americans ‘Want to Be Successful’
description: In a “Fox & Friends” interview, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser also criticized protesters as more concerned with what he called “virtue signaling” than in coming up with “solutions.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has repeatedly bragged about what he has done for Black America, pointing to his administration’s funding for Black colleges and universities, the creation of so-called opportunity zones and criminal justice reform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Lorraine Bracco Goes Searching For Her Sicilian Slice of Life
description: The actress, of “Goodfellas” and “The Sopranos” fame, is the unlikely star of her own HGTV show, “My Big Italian Adventure.”
content: When people ask Lorraine Bracco how she’s doing these days, the actress said she usually gives the same answer. “I say I’m crazy,” she explained. “A little nutty, but good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Colleges slash budgets during the pandemic.
description: As it resurges across the United States, the coronavirus is forcing universities large and small to make deep and possibly lasting cuts to close widening budget shortfalls.
content: As it resurges across the United States, the coronavirus is forcing universities large and small to make deep and possibly lasting cuts to close widening budget shortfalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: New Parents, You Won’t Regret Keeping a Journal
description: A baby book may require too much time and energy, but you and your child will treasure a few notes about this time.
content: After my daughter was born, I moved into my parents’ house in New Jersey for three weeks with my husband. As a clueless first-time parent, I knew I would need their guidance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Is It Safe to Ask Whether Trump’s Days Are Numbered?
description: Just posing the question gives us the willies.
content: Gail Collins: Well Bret, the election’s next week. OK, you probably knew that. But let’s take a look back. Which part are you going to miss most? The debates? The polls? The chance to hear Donald Trump announce that he’s done more for Black Americans than any other president, with the “possible exception” of Abraham Lincoln?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: In Madagascar, Endangered Lemurs Find a Private Refuge
description: Climate change is shifting the habitats of endangered species and requiring conservation scientists to think outside traditional park boundaries.
content: SAMBAVA, Madagascar — Madagascar has always been one of the best places on Earth to study the natural world. Seventy percent of its species are found nowhere else — the largest concentration of endemic wildlife anywhere. In the last 10 years alone, scientists have discovered 40 new mammals, 69 amphibians, 61 reptiles, 42 invertebrates and 385 plants in the country. Its parks are ecotourism destinations and points of national pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: A Teacher, His Killer and the Failure of French Integration
description: For generations, public schools assimilated immigrant children into French society by instilling the nation’s ideals. The beheading of a teacher has raised doubts about whether that model still works.
content: ÉVREUX, France — They could have easily shared the same classroom — the immigrant teenager and the veteran teacher known for his commitment to instilling the nation’s ideals, in a relationship that had turned waves of newcomers into French citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: What Went Wrong for the Patriots? Everything
description: Bill Belichick blamed “offense, defense, special teams, running, passing, defending the run, defending the pass, ball security, tackling, blocking.”
content: Late last season, the New England Patriots were 10-1 and considered a favorite to win a seventh Super Bowl. The team’s downfall since then has been beyond striking, and not just because the Patriots have won only four of their last 12 games after Sunday’s 33-6 thumping at the hands of the San Francisco 49ers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How to Deal With a Crisis of Misinformation’
description: In this lesson, students examine their own information-consuming and sharing habits, then learn practical tips for thinking critically about news.
content: Featured Article: “How to Deal With a Crisis of Misinformation” by Brian X. Chen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter and Tim Gruber
title: As a Coach and a Cop in Minneapolis, Where Would He Draw the Line?
description: While his city struggles with the pandemic and wounds laid bare by George Floyd’s killing, Charles Adams embodies the everyday people trying to make change.
content: On the sidelines and in the streets, caught in the riptide of race and reconciliation, Charles Adams prided himself on keeping a cool optimism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Canapari, M.D
title: How to Prepare Babies and Kids for the End of Daylight Saving Time
description: For parents of small children, ‘falling back’ doesn’t mean an extra hour in bed. But the right plan can help ease the change.
content: The beginning of autumn brings many milestones: crisp weather, changing leaves and jack-o’-lanterns. Much less welcome if you have an early-rising toddler, autumn also brings the end of daylight saving time, commonly known as “falling back,” when much of the Northern Hemisphere will set their clocks back one hour, returning to standard time. In the United States this year, daylight saving time will end at 2 a.m. on Sunday, Nov. 1, 2020, and will return in the spring, at 2 a.m. on Sunday, March 14, 2021, when the clocks “spring ahead” one hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Jeannette Williams-Parker, Nurse in a Virus Hot Spot, Dies at 48
description: She was the first nurse in West Virginia to die of Covid-19. “She just never thought it would happen to her,” her mother said.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff
title: They Did Not Vote in 2016. Why They Plan to Skip the Election Again.
description: Between a third and a half of all eligible voters typically stay home during presidential elections.
content: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa. — Like nearly half of all the eligible voters in her county in 2016, Keyana Fedrick did not vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: The Fox News president and several anchors were advised to quarantine after possible virus exposure.
description: The president of Fox News and several anchors are quarantining after a positive virus test at the network.
content: The president of Fox News and several of the network’s top anchors have been advised to quarantine after being exposed to someone on a private flight who later tested positive for the coronavirus, two people with direct knowledge of the situation said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Twitter to Highlight Accurate Voting Information
description: The effort is meant to preemptively debunk some false and misleading information about the election.
content: Twitter’s emphasis on up-to-the-second posts has made the site a must-visit destination for people to find the latest in news and current events. It has also made Twitter a vessel for the spread of false information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberly Bradley
title: East Germany’s Love Affair With Angela Davis
description: An exhibition looks back at a point in the 1970s when the philosopher and activist was a state-promoted hero behind the Iron Curtain.
content: DRESDEN, Germany — The philosopher, feminist and Black liberation activist Angela Davis is everywhere right now. In the wake of Black Lives Matter protests around the world, TV networks, magazines and newspapers have turned to her, drawing on her decades of activism and scholarship to explain the current moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Have Covid-19 Antibodies. Finally I Know How to Help.
description: Nothing says Peak 2020 like donating antibodies while watching someone get married on your phone.
content: NASHVILLE — I got sick in February on a trip to New York. Every time I stepped into an elevator, someone was coughing. On my last day in town, I found myself out of breath walking up a small hill, though I walk on hilly trails nearly every day. At home that night, I went straight to bed. I thought I was just tired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: In a Must-Win Game 6, Rays Plan to Turn Up the Aggressiveness
description: Tampa Bay Manager Kevin Cash said he felt like his pitchers had been too conservative so far in the World Series. Fortunately for the Rays, it will be Blake Snell, their ace, on the mound on Tuesday.
content: The Tampa Bay Rays, with the third-lowest payroll in Major League Baseball this year, have plenty of players who are not household names. How many people outside Tampa could spot Brandon Lowe walking down a street, or pick out Joey Wendle at the mall?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Gaza Court Convicts Peace Activists for Video Call With Israelis
description: The court ruled that the defendants would not spend more time in jail. Their video call crossed the hard line Hamas takes on many interactions between Palestinians and Israelis.
content: JERUSALEM — A military court in the Gaza Strip convicted three Palestinian peace activists of “weakening revolutionary spirit” on Monday for their role in holding a video call with Israelis in April, but it ordered the authorities to release the two who remained in jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: How the Trump Era Has Strained, and Strengthened, Politically Mixed Marriages
description: Fewer people want to date those with different political views. But couples are also talking through political issues more.
content: There are few remaining areas of American life in which people aren’t sorting themselves by political allegiances — including romantic relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: If the Shoe Floats
description: Over the decades, a mass of flotsam from a freighter accident has inspired scientific discovery, urban legend and, now, an art exhibition commemorating the Great Sneaker Spill of 1990.
content: It seemingly happened so long ago that the event has assumed elements of urban legend — the saga of the Great Sneaker Spill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘It Can’t Happen Here’ Review: A Not-So-Subtle Slide Into Autocracy
description: Sinclair Lewis’s 1930s novel-turned-stage play about the rise of fascism in America returns as an audio drama from Berkeley Rep.
content: The 1936 presidential election was mere days away, in a United States brought to its knees by the Great Depression, when the Federal Theater Project rolled out a headline-grabbing new show — “It Can’t Happen Here,” a play by the Nobel laureate Sinclair Lewis based on his sweeping anti-fascist novel that a skittish Hollywood had recently, notoriously, pulled from the production slate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Head of Virginia Military Institute Resigns Amid Review of Racism on Campus
description: A week after the governor ordered an investigation into reports of racism at the college, Gen. J.H. Binford Peay III says the governor and other officials have lost confidence in his leadership.
content: The Virginia Military Institute’s superintendent resigned on Monday, a week after Virginia’s governor ordered an independent investigation into allegations of systemic racism at the state-supported military college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Virginia Mollenkott, 88, Dies; Feminist Found Liberation in the Bible
description: A Christian evangelical who was shunned for her lesbianism, she became an influential scholar of the Bible, finding in it acceptance of L.G.B.T.Q. people.
content: Prominent Christian evangelicals prayed for her destruction, while others say Virginia Ramey Mollenkott saved their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: China Aims to End Extreme Poverty, but Covid-19 Exposes Gaps
description: The pandemic has worsened longstanding conditions that have widened inequality, hindering Xi Jinping’s vow to “leave no one behind.”
content: Xu Rudong, a farmer in eastern China, thought he had left poverty behind long ago. He turned a small plot of land into a flourishing field of leeks, selling enough to pay for luxuries like fish and meat for his wife and four children. He even had money left over to buy an electric scooter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Song Exploder’ Reveals the Eureka Moments Behind the Hits
description: The new Netflix show deftly explores the making of songs from R.E.M., Alicia Keys, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Ty Dolla Sign. It’s exhilarating TV.
content: Netflix might offer flashier, more stunt-studded interview shows than “Song Exploder,” one, say, in which Lizzo oversees the loss of David Letterman’s virginity as a rapping flutist. But would any of those devote even a minute to the glories of the flexatone? That’s the surgical-looking percussion instrument that, once shaken and bent, can sound like a triangle on a cartoon acid trip. The musician Ty Dolla Sign uses one on his song “LA,” and he praises it in the maiden season of “Song Exploder,” except, dang it, he can’t remember what the thing is called. The show’s creator and host, Hrishikesh Hirway, fills the blank in. Ty Dolla’s attempt to jog his memory has the adorable comprehensiveness of certain game show contestants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Nurses Are at High Risk for Covid Among Health Workers, C.D.C. Says
description: A new study looked at the high numbers of health care workers hospitalized during the early months of the pandemic.
content: Among health care workers, nurses in particular have been at significant risk of contracting Covid-19, according to a new analysis of hospitalized patients by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Ducker
title: Chill Vibes, Minus the Wind Chimes: It’s a New Day for New Age Music
description: A genre known for cheesiness is thriving once again in Los Angeles, taking root on the label Leaving Records.
content: Nailah Hunter grew up in a household where magic was considered demonic, so her parents didn’t let her read the “Harry Potter” books. Her father was a pastor in the South Los Angeles neighborhood Ladera Heights and she sang at his church, and later wrote songs on acoustic guitar and performed in her high school’s choir. She also read fantasy novels and listened to Gary Stadler, a fanciful composer whose titles are filled with “fairy” or “faerie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: It’s Braising Season!
description: Take your time in cooking, and simmer away some chicken legs or beef cheeks.
content: Here we go again. The trees are in their autumn beauty, but the week begins suspiciously like all the other weeks we’ve weathered since March, with mild surprise, tempered annoyance: It’s Monday again, so soon? We trudge out to work. We drive or bicycle to work. We plod across bedrooms to work, to look for work, to assess reality, to learn as best we can. We activate our cameras, our microphones. We do as we have done for so long, and soon we think about dinner, because it is dinner that will be our balm, that will offer solace against the monotony, that offers our best chance at joy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Guess What? More Time Makes a Fashion Show Much Better
description: Or so it seems judging by Celine, Comme des Garçons, Michael Kors and other renegades that escaped the fashion system, at least this once.
content: The desire to buck a stifling system can make allies of even the most unlikely names. Thus emerged the breakaway contingent of fashion brands from Tokyo to Antwerp to New York that seized the pandemic-spawned moment of largely digital shows to rethink when and where they would reveal their new collections. Opting out of the seasonal four-week, four-city calendar, they chose instead to unveil their work as it was ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison P. Davis
title: Some Advice About Ghosts and Ghosting, From a Paranormal Investigator
description: In “Life With the Afterlife,” Amy Bruni reveals the lessons she’s learned helping ghosts and the people they visit.
content: LIFE WITH THE AFTERLIFE 13 Truths I Learned About Ghosts By Amy Bruni
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex V. Cipolle
title: After Honing His Painting Skills as a Soldier, an Artist Finds His Voice
description: In Iraq, Samir Khurshid had to paint portraits of Saddam Hussein. In Oregon, he’s still painting, and his former life makes its way into his work.
content: This article is part of our latest Fine Arts & Exhibits special report, which focuses on how art endures and inspires, even in the darkest of times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Spirits Rise in Old, Repurposed Churches
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 26, 2020.
content: “There’s sadness when a worshiping space changes, but this is a whole different kind of sanctuary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Cao Li
title: Ant Challenged Beijing and Prospered. Now It Toes the Line.
description: The tech giant, which is preparing for a mega I.P.O., has transformed personal finance in China. Regulators have taken notice.
content: As Jack Ma of Alibaba helped turn China into the world’s biggest e-commerce market over the past two decades, he was also vowing to pull off a more audacious transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Swing-District Democrats, Defying Predictions, Poised to Help Keep House
description: Once regarded as the most vulnerable incumbents, many Democrats who carried Trump districts in 2018 are poised to win re-election, boosting the party’s chances of building its House majority.
content: HENRICO COUNTY, Va. — When Representative Abigail Spanberger, the Democrat running for re-election in the conservative-leaning Richmond suburbs, arrived to debate her Republican opponent on a recent evening, she received a heroine’s welcome, loudly cheered by supporters on both sides of the street who held blue balloons and handmade signs praising her accomplishments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: After breakneck process, Amy Coney Barrett is set to be confirmed to the Supreme Court.
description: Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s expected confirmation to the Supreme Court tonight caps a breakneck nomination process and will hand conservatives a clear 6-3 majority.
content: The Senate was poised on Monday to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett, a conservative appeals court judge and protégé of former Justice Antonin Scalia, to the Supreme Court, handing President Trump a coveted achievement just eight days before the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Spain, Covid-19, Airbnb: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Dana Rubinstein
title: Fights Erupt During ‘Jews for Trump’ Rally in Manhattan
description: Eleven people were arrested, and protesters screamed at Rudy Giuliani. Separately, a police officer was suspended for voicing support for the president on the job.
content: Political tensions over the upcoming presidential election escalated on New York City’s streets on Sunday, as supporters of President Trump clashed with counterprotesters during a day of demonstrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Driverless Cars Go Humble to Get Real
description: Recent developments point to promise for driverless car technology, if we stay realistic.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: It Might Become the Scariest Part of Your Commute: The Elevator
description: Touch-free buttons, foot pedals, holograms — New York City buildings scramble to make the ride up feel safer.
content: Buttons that you can press by just pointing at them. Others that appear to float in the air, holograms seen more in sci-fi films than office buildings. Staggered employee arrivals and departures, and the rethinking, or even elimination, of the outside lunch break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Infection of Pence aides raises new questions about the administration’s response to the virus.
description: After officials acknowledged over the weekend that another coronavirus outbreak had struck the White House, infecting Vice President Mike Pence’s chief of staff and four other top aides, Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, essentially offering a verbal shrug on CNN on Sunday: “We’re not going to control the pandemic.”
content: After officials acknowledged over the weekend that another coronavirus outbreak had struck the White House, infecting Vice President Mike Pence’s chief of staff and four other top aides, Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, essentially offering a verbal shrug on CNN on Sunday: “We’re not going to control the pandemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 26, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 26, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 26, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Do You Have the Heart for Marijuana?
description: Research suggests that smoking marijuana carries many of the same cardiovascular health hazards as smoking tobacco.
content: Do you have the heart to safely smoke pot? Maybe not, a growing body of medical reports suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump’s Manufacturing Promises Disappoint as Economy Sours
description: Foxconn’s failure to deliver on a Wisconsin project underscores the limits of the president’s power to make companies bend to his will.
content: WASHINGTON — At a 2018 groundbreaking ceremony for a Foxconn plant in Wisconsin, President Trump declared that the factory would be the “eighth wonder of the world” — a $10 billion hub that would hire 13,000 workers to make flat-screen televisions in America’s heartland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley, Makiko Inoue and Hikari Hida
title: Japan’s New Leader Sets Ambitious Goal of Carbon Neutrality by 2050
description: The announcement, coming weeks after a similar pledge by China, will require a major overhaul of the infrastructure in Japan, which remains heavily dependent on fossil fuels.
content: TOKYO — Japan will be carbon neutral by 2050, its prime minister said on Monday, making an ambitious pledge to sharply accelerate the country’s global warming targets, even as it plans to build more than a dozen new coal-burning power plants in the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: All About Ant Group, the Next Big Tech I.P.O.
description: The tech giant’s coming share sale will be among the largest ever. But the company has made most of its impact in just one country: China.
content: One of China’s most influential tech companies, the internet finance titan Ant Group, is poised to raise a boatload of cash by selling shares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Trump’s Weakened Hold on Long Island Puts 2 G.O.P. House Seats at Risk
description: Peter King is leaving Congress, and Lee Zeldin could be vulnerable. The elections in the two districts will be “a referendum on Trump,” a strategist said.
content: MASSAPEQUA PARK, N.Y. — Just to the right of the register at Village Wines & Spirits, a bottle of Virginia chardonnay bore a label that suggested that it was best paired with Republicans: It was from Trump Winery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lou Stoppard
title: Can Fashion Photography Survive the Pandemic?
description: Glossy magazines are going digital. Brands are shutting down. The fantasy images of women in ball gowns with elephants may soon be no more.
content: In the 1930s and ’40s, when the photographer Louise Dahl-Wolfe took models out of the studio and onto location — shooting them poolside for Harper’s Bazaar, say — she was making pictures about freedom, about women’s changing role in society, about travel and leisure culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Should You FedEx Your Ballot? No
description: Lady Gaga shared a photo of herself on Twitter holding a ballot and a FedEx envelope. But experts urged people to use the United States Postal Service or a secure ballot drop box instead.
content: With Election Day a week away, those who have waited until nearly the last minute to vote by mail may be considering turning to an express carrier, thinking that may expedite the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Tells Coronavirus, ‘I Surrender’
description: The president plays the climate-denial playbook on a pandemic.
content: As we head into the final stretch of the election, Covid-19 is on a roll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Music Biographer Peter Guralnick’s New Book Covers Many Subjects — Including Himself
description: “Looking to Get Lost” features writing by the acclaimed biographer about Ray Charles, Merle Haggard and others, as well as about his own life and career.
content: Peter Guralnick is a commanding figure in music biography; his lives of Elvis Presley, Sam Cooke and Sam Phillips are, as the Michelin guides used to say, worth the journey. His new book is a collection made up primarily of decades-old profiles and essays, some rewritten. It’s not so commanding. There’s something warmed-over about it. Reading it is like watching Merle Haggard perform in an uptight club with a quiet policy and a two-drink minimum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A New Covid Outbreak at the White House
description: The administration plays defense after Pence aides test positive: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Arts Bailout in U.K. Buys Time, but No Peace of Mind
description: In Liverpool, England, whose tourist trade is built on culture, more than 40 venues received money from a $2 billion fund. That life support lasts until April.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — One recent afternoon, Liam Naughton was standing in the main room of the Invisible Wind Factory, a vast music venue and arts space he runs in a formerly industrial area of Liverpool, which has been largely shuttered since March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Merrill D. Oliver
title: Supreme Court, Election 2020, U.S. Virus Surge: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Von Diaz
title: Finding Strength in Sofrito in Puerto Rico
description: Hardship and hurricanes have shaped the island’s food for centuries. But chefs and home cooks make magic with whatever ingredients they have.
content: From her home in Cayey, P.R., the chef Natalia Vallejo speaks with measured sadness about shutting down Cocina al Fondo, her intimate farm-to-table restaurant in San Juan. But the closing amid this particular crisis feels different than if there had been a storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: pneumatic
description: This word has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Field: Why Suburban Women Changed Their Minds
description: In 2016, white women in the suburbs helped deliver President Trump the White House. Four years later, they could be the ones to take it away from him.
content: In America’s increasingly divided political landscape, it can be hard to imagine almost any voter switching sides. One demographic group has provided plenty of exceptions: white suburban women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Crush of Early Voters Makes for Long Waits in N.Y.C.
description: For the first time ever, New Yorkers cast their ballots early for a presidential election, sometimes standing in line for five hours.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Yan Zhuang
title: Women on Qatar Airways Flight Are Strip-Searched, Sparking Outrage in Australia
description: Female passengers said they were pulled from a Sydney-bound flight in Doha and given a medically invasive exam to see if they had recently given birth after an abandoned newborn was found in an airport bathroom.
content: DARWIN, Australia — The Qatar Airways flight bound for Sydney, Australia, had been mysteriously stalled on the tarmac in Doha for more than three hours when an announcement boomed through the cabin. All female passengers had to take their passports and disembark immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Eight Small New York Theaters Sue Cuomo Over Pandemic Restrictions
description: The lawsuit argues that if bowling alleys, casinos and gyms can open, why can’t performance venues with fewer than 200 seats?
content: A group of eight small theaters and comedy clubs in New York City has filed a lawsuit challenging the closing of their venues during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: A Timeline of the Nxivm Sex Cult Case
description: Keith Raniere, the group’s leader, styled himself a visionary, but a jury found him guilty of racketeering, sex trafficking and other charges.
content: [Read our coverage of Keith Raniere’s sentencing.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal and Michael Rothfeld
title: Inside Decades of Nepotism and Bungling at the N.Y.C. Elections Board
description: Some staffers read or watch Netflix at the office, while others punch in and then go shopping or to the gym, current and former employees said.
content: The official who oversees voter registration in New York City is the 80-year-old mother of a former congressman. The director of Election Day operations is a close friend of Manhattan’s Republican chairwoman. The head of ballot management is the son of a former Brooklyn Democratic district leader. And the administrative manager is the wife of a City Council member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With Title in Sight, the Dodgers Are Armed and Ready to Get Creative
description: Los Angeles has a wealth of pitching options for two more potential World Series games. If the club can get the combination right, it could mean the end of a long title drought.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — It seems to be a dream setup for a modern front office, a chance to write the script for the game that clinches a title. On the mound for the Los Angeles Dodgers in Game 6 of the World Series on Tuesday: Tony Gonsolin, who served as an opener for a band of six relievers — three lefties and three righties — in his start last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: With Weakness Among Hispanic Voters, Biden Trails in Texas
description: Large Democratic gains among white suburbanites suggest risks down the ballot for Republicans in congressional and state House races, our poll shows.
content: President Trump maintains a narrow lead in Texas, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll on Monday, as he faces a rebellion in the state’s once overwhelmingly Republican suburbs but survives with support from an unlikely ally, Hispanic voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ming Cho Lee, Fabled Set Designer, Is Dead at 90
description: His work in theater, dance and opera helped redefine American stage design.
content: Ming Cho Lee, an innovative and influential designer who created sets for hundreds of plays, dance works and operas, and whose ideas continue to influence the field, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Barack Obama and LeBron James are joining forces in a late push to increase Black voter turnout.
description: Mr. Obama sat for an interview with the N.B.A. star as a part of the athlete’s More Than A Vote initiative.
content: Former President Barack Obama will continue his efforts to increase Black voter turnout ahead of the election, including an interview with the basketball star LeBron James set to be published this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Only 26% of N.Y.C. Students Attend In-Person Classes, Far From Goal
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio is facing a major test: Will children return to public schools over the next few weeks?
content: [Read more on NYC school closings due to Covid-19]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Tractor Flips During Hayride in Illinois, Killing One and Injuring 17
description: The injured included 15 children ranging from 1 to 12 years old, the State Police said.
content: One woman was killed and 17 others were injured during a hayride in western Illinois late Saturday when the tractor and the trailer used for the leisurely excursion overturned, the State Police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: With a little more than a week until Election Day, Trump and Biden make their closing pitches on ‘60 Minutes.’
description: President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered sharply divergent visions for the country as they made their closing pitches on ‘60 Minutes.’
content: Nine days before Election Day, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered sharply divergent visions for the country — including the coronavirus pandemic, the economy and foreign policy — in wide-ranging interviews on “60 Minutes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Jona Frank: Between Reality and Fantasy
description: From André Breton to Alison Bechdel, memoir writers have turned the genre upside down. Now a photographer recreates her troubled suburban childhood in a book, casting a movie star — Laura Dern — as her mother.
content: “In each project I am asking the same questions — about becoming and identity and how we find ourselves,” said Jona Frank, a Los Angeles-based photographer who has made a series of portraits of subcultures in American high schools, a British boxing club and a Christian college in Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Are ‘Kidfluencers’ Making Our Kids Fat?
description: Popular YouTube channels often bombard young children with thinly veiled ads for junk food, a new study finds.
content: Parents beware: Many YouTube channels that are wildly popular with young children are targeting them with thinly veiled ads for sugary beverages and junk food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Zachary Small
title: How Long Can N.Y.C. Museums Survive at 25 Percent Capacity?
description: Visiting during the pandemic can feel a bit lonely. Museum directors worry that will persist far into 2021.
content: On a weekday afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum, Carolyn and Joel Jacobson ambled through the American art galleries, alone with George Bellows’s smirking “Newsboy” and a bronze bust of Abraham Lincoln.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump will hold three Pennsylvania rallies today, Pence goes to Minnesota, no Biden events.
description: There are eight days until Election Day. Here are the schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Monday, Oct. 26. All times are Eastern time.
content: There are eight days until Election Day. Here are the schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Monday, Oct. 26. All times are Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu and Michael D. Shear
title: Rallies Are the Core of Trump’s Campaign, and a Font of Lies and Misinformation
description: A recent rally in Wisconsin was typical. In 90 minutes, President Trump made 131 false or inaccurate statements.
content: Two minutes and 28 seconds into a campaign rally on a recent Saturday night in Janesville, Wis., President Trump delivered his first lie.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hillary Clinton Says It’s Different This Time
description: The 2016 Democratic candidate was certain she’d win four years ago. Now, she’s even more bullish that Biden will.
content: “We are advantaged — unfortunately — by four years of a record from Trump,” Hillary Clinton says as she predicts big wins for Democrats in 2020. The former candidate has been a lightning rod for the right, and has been called a lizard, a murderer and a human trafficker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Susan Hendl, Ballet Master and Dancer, Dies at 73
description: After dancing for George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins, she became a longtime teacher at the New York City Ballet.
content: Susan Hendl, a dancer and longtime teacher at New York City Ballet, who staged works by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins and inspired generations of dancers, died on Oct. 12 in Manhattan. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Facio-Krajcer, Will Wright and Johnny Diaz
title: Thousands Forced to Evacuate From California Fires
description: Two firefighters were injured and about 90,800 people ordered to evacuate near Irvine, Calif., the authorities said. An evacuation warning also went into effect for the area south of Diamond Bar in Los Angeles County.
content: IRVINE, Calif. — Two firefighters were gravely injured and tens of thousands of Californians were forced to flee their homes as two wildfires continued to spread on Tuesday through Orange County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Stein
title: Kazakhstan, Reversing Itself, Embraces ‘Borat’ as Very Nice
description: After banning the first Sacha Baron Cohen satire, the country has created tourism ads adopting its catchphrase.
content: In 2005, Dennis Keen, a high school junior in Los Angeles, was applying for a summer exchange program. After not much deliberation, he decided it would be punky and funny to forgo France and Spain and go to Kazakhstan. “People didn’t know where it was,” Mr. Keen said. “In Kazakhstan, there’s pre-Borat and post-Borat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Respecting Children’s Pain
description: A new study challenges those who care for children to end what researchers say is the common undertreatment of pain in children, starting at birth.
content: In a new report on pediatric pain in the British medical journal The Lancet, a commission of experts, including scientists, doctors, psychologists, parents and patients, challenged those who take care of children to end what they described as the common undertreatment of pain in children, starting at birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘This Is Us’ and ‘The Haunting’
description: The NBC family drama returns, the classic haunted-house horror airs on TCM and Snoop Dogg presents at the BET Hip Hop Awards.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 26-Nov. 1. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What Alex Padilla Wants California Voters to Know
description: Monday: The secretary of state talks about voting in person. Also: Fires and wind cause dangerous conditions in Northern California.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: For Best Results, Eat This Roti Immediately
description: In Los Angeles, the chef Rashida Holmes grows her small food business to meet the demand for comforting West Indian food.
content: LOS ANGELES — There’s more than one way to laminate paratha-style roti, to fill the dough with fine layers of fat and bring the bread to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.6 Million Homes in California
description: A 1929 Tudor Revival house in Altadena, a penthouse condominium in San Diego and a Bavarian-inspired chalet in Truckee.
content: This home was designed by Garrett Van Pelt, an architect who worked on a number of projects in Pasadena and Altadena in the 1920s and 1930s, both as a solo practitioner and as part of a firm he established with Sylvanus Marston, another well-known local architect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil and Jeré Longman
title: World Rugby Bars Transgender Women, Baffling Players
description: World Rugby is the first international sports federation to block transgender women from global competitions, even though it has long preached a motto of inclusivity.
content: Grace McKenzie started playing rugby in 2018. While at a technology conference in San Francisco, she was approached by a few ruggers who recommended that she try out for a recreational team. As a transgender athlete, McKenzie jumped at the chance to participate in a sport whose international governing body promoted the motto “Rugby for All.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson
title: In the Pandemic, a Shifting Ballot Debate on Legalizing Drugs
description: Marijuana measures are on the ballot in several states that once resisted them. Oregon would go further with a proposal to decriminalize drugs like heroin, cocaine and methamphetamine.
content: Oregon has an addiction problem. Pockets of rural poverty, chronic homelessness and cities with lots of young people have given the state one of the highest rates of substance abuse in the nation. It is also, because there is so little money allocated to it, one of the toughest places to get treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Research shows that counties that have forced residents to wear masks in public have had fewer infections.
content: They’re restrictive, tedious and hotly contested, but since the early days of the pandemic we’ve known masks to be an efficient and cost-effective way to help prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Georgia, Once Reliably Red, Is Suddenly a Battleground. What Happened?
description: Joe Biden could win the state because Republicans have failed to keep up with its diverse population and shifting suburban politics.
content: WATKINSVILLE, Ga. — For years, state House District 119 was a safely Republican seat in the Georgia Legislature, having been carved out of conservative suburbs along the south side of Athens, a liberal college town, to maximize Republican votes. This year, Jonathan Wallace, a Democrat, could win it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Walker Pickering
title: How the Virus Slowed the Booming Wind Energy Business
description: Renewable energy developers have struggled to finish projects as the pandemic disrupts construction and global supply chains.
content: Even as businesses around the world shut down this spring, executives at EDF Renewables were hopeful they would finish installing 99 wind turbines in southern Nebraska before a year-end deadline. Then, in early April, the pandemic dealt a big blow to the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Bid to Steal Home Offers a Taste of the 20th Century
description: No, it wasn’t 1955 in Yankee Stadium, but yes, Manuel Margot tried to match Jackie Robinson in the World Series.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — As he charged for home plate in the fourth inning on Sunday night, carrying the hopes of the Tampa Bay Rays, Manuel Margot could have been sprinting backward through time. You almost expected him to burst through to a different dimension, back to a distant World Series on a golden afternoon, when being daring on the bases was cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Why N.Y.C.’s Economic Recovery May Lag the Rest of the Country’s
description: More than one million residents are out of work, and the unemployment rate is nearly double the national average.
content: New York, whose diversified economy had fueled unparalleled job growth in recent years, is now facing a bigger challenge in recovering from the pandemic than almost any other major city in the country. More than one million residents are out of work, and the unemployment rate is nearly double the national average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Colleges Slash Budgets in the Pandemic, With ‘Nothing Off-Limits’
description: Liberal arts departments, graduate student aid and even tenured teaching positions are targets as the coronavirus causes shortfalls.
content: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney, Melina Delkic, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A surge in hospitalizations is straining some U.S. health care facilities.
description: With the coronavirus spreading out of control in many parts of the United States and daily case counts setting records, health experts say it is only a matter of time before hospitals start to reach the breaking point.
content: With the coronavirus spreading out of control in many parts of the United States and daily case counts setting records, health experts say it is only a matter of time before hospitals start to reach the breaking point.

author: By Mark Landler
title: Taking a Page From White House, Boris Johnson Bets on Live Press Briefings
description: The British prime minister has hired a well-connected former political journalist to run newly televised press briefings, adopting an American ritual that grew increasingly contentious under President Trump.
content: LONDON — Britain and the United States have been living under the same political weather vane for the past four years, so it is fitting that Prime Minister Boris Johnson is borrowing one of the White House’s most familiar daily rituals, the televised press briefing, for 10 Downing Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Making the Songs Pop in ‘Bad Hair’
description: Justin Simien, the writer and director of the 1989-set horror-comedy, also wrote some of the retro-sounding songs. Though he’s known for “Dear White People,” music has long been a hobby.
content: A murderous weave is the main attraction of the horror comedy “Bad Hair,” but a few catchy tunes play a memorable supporting role. The movie (streaming on Hulu) takes place in 1989 and is mostly set at a Black music TV network, at a time when new jack swing was a mainstay on the pop charts. That style, popularized by artists like Janet Jackson, Jody Watley and Bobby Brown, fused funk, jazz and R&B into infectiously danceable grooves. The music inspired the film’s writer and director Justin Simien at a young age.
source.name: The New York Times
